prompt: FOAAS (Fuck Off As A Service) provides a modern, RESTful
response:
FOAAS (Fuck Off As A Service) provides a modern, RESTful API for a simple use case: removing users from your service. FOAAS is part of the Push the Web Forward project, which focuses on promoting and standardizing an approach to API development that avoids some of the less robust habits we've picked up over the years.
Their API uses Status Code Indication, which provides error response codes in an easy-to-read format for errors like user does not exist, bad input, and outages. This helps both humans and machines to easily see the status of their requests (200 responses will show the response payload like any other request; error responses provide the error code and message, all on the same response).
In the process of building the API, we realized that we weren't sure what error response status codes most people would expect to see, so we built a quick survey with some of the most common API error codes. Our goals were to a) see where the expectations for error responses lie, and b) see if folks would be more likely to adopt Status Code Indication if it matched commonly expected status codes.
FOAAS uses error codes that are inspired by status codes that are commonly used in other APIs (like GitHub and GitLab), but they are not identical. The idea is that they are familiar, but a little more descriptive. FOAAS also documents

They fuck you up, your mum and dad, the poem They begins. First published in the collection The Waste Land and Other Poems (1925), and reprinted and anthologised since, They is often thought of as a stand-alone poem, but it ends with a line about how the speakers parents had the time of their lives in the war. They belongs, then, to the Waste Land series, a sequence of poems exploring the fall-out from the Great War. The term Waste Land is a translation of the Old English word for England, referring particularly to the flatlands of eastern England.
The poem describes the effect upon the speaker of his parents experiences during the war, particularly his mothers. This can be related to the general impact upon women in the war  women who stayed in the UK and, like the speakers mother, were left to get on with everyday life without their husbands.
The poem moves by abrupt changes of perspective  the child sees people as distorted and grotesque, as when his mother looks like a squashed Catholics idea of the Virgin  before moving into more objective descriptions of peoples physical deformities, the products of the wars violence.
